elements.content: The hydrothermal reaction of 2-(1H-tetrazol-5-yl)pyrimidine (HL) with NH3VO3 and CuCl2 afforded an unusual inorganic–organic complex, [Cu3(L)2(VO3)4] n , with a three-dimensional structure. Magnetic studies show that this material is a heterometallic homospin ferrimagnet with T N = 10 K.
elements.clean_text: The hydrothermal reaction of 2-(1H-tetrazol-5-yl)pyrimidine (HL) with NH3VO3 and CuCl2 afforded an unusual inorganic-organic complex, [Cu3(L)2(VO3)4] n , with a three-dimensional structure. Magnetic studies show that this material is a heterometallic homospin ferrimagnet with T N = 10 K.

elements.content: There is currently extensive interest in the design and synthesis of inorganic–organic complex materials due to their fascinating structural diversity and potential applications in the fields of magnetism, photochemistry, electrical conductivity, catalysis, and adsorption. One of the recent important advances in this field is the combination of secondary organic transition-metal complexes and polyoxometalates by molecular assembly to produce new magnetic materials. The secondary metal sites and organic ligands can guide the overall structures and properties of the materials. Thus, in principle, it is possible to modify the structures and properties of such materials or to design new materials by the sound choices of the secondary metal ions and organic ligands, although this remains rather primitive. In these materials, the exchange coupling among paramagnetic centers typically leads to a ferromagnetic or antiferromagnetic behavior, whereas the ferrimagnetism has not been observed to date.
elements.clean_text: There is currently extensive interest in the design and synthesis of inorganic-organic complex materials due to their fascinating structural diversity and potential applications in the fields of magnetism, photochemistry, electrical conductivity, catalysis, and adsorption. One of the recent important advances in this field is the combination of secondary organic transition-metal complexes and polyoxometalates by molecular assembly to produce new magnetic materials. The secondary metal sites and organic ligands can guide the overall structures and properties of the materials. Thus, in principle, it is possible to modify the structures and properties of such materials or to design new materials by the sound choices of the secondary metal ions and organic ligands, although this remains rather primitive. In these materials, the exchange coupling among paramagnetic centers typically leads to a ferromagnetic or antiferromagnetic behavior, whereas the ferrimagnetism has not been observed to date.

elements.content: It is well-known that the conventional ferrimagnetic systems always contain two kinds of spin carriers (heterospin), which alternate regularly and interact antiferromagnetically. In contrast, homospin ferrimagnetic systems contain only one type of spin carrier (in the present case CuII ions with S = 1/2) that in spite of the antiferromagnetic coupling lead to an noncancellation as a result of a particular topological arrangement of the spins. Homospin ferrimagnets have been relatively less investigated and are a synthetic challenge, because the ferrimagnetic conditions for the noncompensation of the magnetic moments are difficult to achieve in compounds containing only one type of spin. Recent studies have indicated that homospin ferrimagnetic materials must have a particular spatial arrangement of the spin carriers that ensures the noncancellation (also termed as “topological ferrimagnetism”). It should also be pointed out that among the reported homospin ferrimagnetic systems, the most common bridging ligands are azido and carboxylato group, and most have a one-dimensional (1D) chain structure, whereas those with a three-dimensional (3D) structure or with other bridging groups are very rare. Furthermore, only a few such systems exhibit long-range ferrimagnetic order, as a ferrimagnet. In this contribution, we report a homospin heterometallic inorganic–organic ferrimagnet, [Cu3(L)2(VO3)4] n (1, L = 5-(pyrimidin-2-yl)tetrazolate) with a 3D structure constructed from vanadium oxide chains linking two-dimensional (2D) tetrazolate−CuII layers. The selection of vanadium oxide and tetrazolate ligand is based on their coordination/linkage diversities and favorable magnetic transfer ability confirmed by several recent reports.
elements.clean_text: It is well-known that the conventional ferrimagnetic systems always contain two kinds of spin carriers (heterospin), which alternate regularly and interact antiferromagnetically. In contrast, homospin ferrimagnetic systems contain only one type of spin carrier (in the present case CuII ions with S = 1/2) that in spite of the antiferromagnetic coupling lead to an noncancellation as a result of a particular topological arrangement of the spins. Homospin ferrimagnets have been relatively less investigated and are a synthetic challenge, because the ferrimagnetic conditions for the noncompensation of the magnetic moments are difficult to achieve in compounds containing only one type of spin. Recent studies have indicated that homospin ferrimagnetic materials must have a particular spatial arrangement of the spin carriers that ensures the noncancellation (also termed as "topological ferrimagnetism"). It should also be pointed out that among the reported homospin ferrimagnetic systems, the most common bridging ligands are azido and carboxylato group, and most have a one-dimensional (1D) chain structure, whereas those with a three-dimensional (3D) structure or with other bridging groups are very rare. Furthermore, only a few such systems exhibit long-range ferrimagnetic order, as a ferrimagnet. In this contribution, we report a homospin heterometallic inorganic-organic ferrimagnet, [Cu3(L)2(VO3)4] n  (1, L = 5-(pyrimidin-2-yl)tetrazolate) with a 3D structure constructed from vanadium oxide chains linking two-dimensional (2D) tetrazolate-CuII layers. The selection of vanadium oxide and tetrazolate ligand is based on their coordination/linkage diversities and favorable magnetic transfer ability confirmed by several recent reports.

elements.content: Green crystal product of 1 was obtained by hydrothermal synthesis in good yield. This material is thermally stable until 320 °C (, Figure 3S). X-ray crystal structure analysis reveals that the framework in 1 consists of coordination polymeric [Cu3(L)2]4n+ layers, which are linked into a 3D structure by vanadium oxide (VO3 –) n chains (Figure ). There are two crystallographically independent CuII centers in the asymmetric unit as shown in Figure 4S (). The central Cu(1) atom is located at a crystallographic inversion center and is coordinated by four trans-related N atoms of two L ligands in the equatorial plane and two O atoms from two vanadium oxide chains at the axial positions, in an elongated octahedral environment [Cu–N = 2.006(2) and 2.046(2) Å; Cu–O = 2.271(2) Å]. However, the Cu(2) adopts an axial-elongated square-pyramidal geometry and is coordinated by two N atoms from two L ligands and three O atoms of the two vanadium oxide chains. The equatorial plane is setup by the two N atoms [Cu–N = 1.990(2) and 2.063(2) Å] and two O atoms [Cu–O = 1.908(2) and 1.945(2) Å] belonging to the two distinct vanadium oxide chains, and the axial position is occupied by the third O atom, with the Cu–O distance of 2.389(2) Å. It is also noteworthy that there exists a weak coordination between Cu(2) and the 4-position tetrazolate N atom of L with the Cu···N separation of 2.821(2) Å. Thus, each Cu(1) center is linked to six adjacent Cu(2) atoms, and each Cu(2) links two Cu(2) and three Cu(1) atoms through L ligands and [VO4] groups. Such linkages can also be regarded as the three-atom NNN, NCN, and OVO bridges considering the need of transferring magnetic coupling. Each L ligand in the [Cu3(L)2]4n+ layer adopts a chelating-bridging coordination mode to link three CuII atoms [one Cu(1) and two Cu(2)] through its two pyrimidine N atoms and the two tetrazolate N atoms in 1- and 3-positions to form a scalene triangle lattice with the Cu···Cu separations of 5.690(2), 5.941(2), and 5.380(2) Å, respectively. This homometallic triangular topologic lattice may be responsible for the ferrimagnetism in 1 (vide infra). The vanadium oxide chain is composed of corner sharing [VO4] tetrahedrons and has also been observed in some reported hybrid vanadium oxide systems. Each [VO4] unit shares two O atoms with two adjacent ones in the chain, and the remaining two O atoms are shared with CuII atoms, to form an inorganic [Cu3(VO3)4]2n+ layer (, Figure 5S). Indeed, in the chain there exist two types of corner sharing [VO4] units with one being bonded to one Cu(1) and one Cu(2) atom and the other one linked to two Cu(2) atoms [Cu(1)–Cu(2) = 5.590(2) and Cu(2)–Cu(2) = 5.532(2) Å]. Thus, each inorganic chain serves to link two adjacent organic-metal coordination layers to produce a 3D framework solid, being reminiscent of a similar composite material, [Cu3(trz)2(VO3)4] n (trz is 1,2,4-triazolate).
elements.clean_text: Green crystal product of 1 was obtained by hydrothermal synthesis in good yield. This material is thermally stable until 320 °C (, Figure 3S). X-ray crystal structure analysis reveals that the framework in 1 consists of coordination polymeric [Cu3(L)2]4n+ layers, which are linked into a 3D structure by vanadium oxide (VO3 -) n  chains (Figure ). There are two crystallographically independent CuII centers in the asymmetric unit as shown in Figure 4S (). The central Cu(1) atom is located at a crystallographic inversion center and is coordinated by four trans-related N atoms of two L ligands in the equatorial plane and two O atoms from two vanadium oxide chains at the axial positions, in an elongated octahedral environment [Cu-N = 2.006(2) and 2.046(2) Å; Cu-O = 2.271(2) Å]. However, the Cu(2) adopts an axial-elongated square-pyramidal geometry and is coordinated by two N atoms from two L ligands and three O atoms of the two vanadium oxide chains. The equatorial plane is setup by the two N atoms [Cu-N = 1.990(2) and 2.063(2) Å] and two O atoms [Cu-O = 1.908(2) and 1.945(2) Å] belonging to the two distinct vanadium oxide chains, and the axial position is occupied by the third O atom, with the Cu-O distance of 2.389(2) Å. It is also noteworthy that there exists a weak coordination between Cu(2) and the 4-position tetrazolate N atom of L with the Cu⋅⋅⋅N separation of 2.821(2) Å. Thus, each Cu(1) center is linked to six adjacent Cu(2) atoms, and each Cu(2) links two Cu(2) and three Cu(1) atoms through L ligands and [VO4] groups. Such linkages can also be regarded as the three-atom NNN, NCN, and OVO bridges considering the need of transferring magnetic coupling. Each L ligand in the [Cu3(L)2]4n+  layer adopts a chelating-bridging coordination mode to link three CuII atoms [one Cu(1) and two Cu(2)] through its two pyrimidine N atoms and the two tetrazolate N atoms in 1- and 3-positions to form a scalene triangle lattice with the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu separations of 5.690(2), 5.941(2), and 5.380(2) Å, respectively. This homometallic triangular topologic lattice may be responsible for the ferrimagnetism in 1 (vide infra). The vanadium oxide chain is composed of corner sharing [VO4] tetrahedrons and has also been observed in some reported hybrid vanadium oxide systems. Each [VO4] unit shares two O atoms with two adjacent ones in the chain, and the remaining two O atoms are shared with CuII atoms, to form an inorganic [Cu3(VO3)4]2n+ layer (, Figure 5S). Thus, each inorganic chain serves to link two adjacent organic-metal coordination layers to produce a 3D framework solid, being reminiscent of a similar composite material, [Cu3(trz)2(VO3)4] n  (trz is 1,2,4-triazolate).

elements.content: (a) Perspective view of 1, showing the two crystallographically different CuII polyhedral sites. The Cu(1) sites are shown in yellow, and the Cu(2) site are in green. The red box and ellipse highlight the {[5-(pyrimidin-2-yl)tetrazolato-(CuII)1.5]2+} n layer (b) and the (VO3 –) n chain (c), respectively. H atoms of the ligand were omitted for clarity. Other atom color codes: orange, V; red, O; blue, N; and white, C.

The red box and ellipse highlight the {[5-(pyrimidin-2-yl)tetrazolato-(CuII)1.5]2+} n  layer (b) and the (VO3 -) n  chain (c), respectively. H atoms of the ligand were omitted for clarity. Other atom color codes: orange, V; red, O; blue, N; and white, C.

elements.content: The magnetic susceptibility data were collected in the temperature range of 2–300 K at an applied field of 10000 Oe. The field dependence was also checked, and the susceptibility data at temperatures below 50 K were measured at an additional applied field of 500 Oe. The molar susceptibilities are calculated using the Cu3 asymmetric unit of the crystal structure, which consists of three CuII atoms [one Cu(2) and two symmetry related Cu(1)] with S = 1/2 and four VV atoms (based on the bond valence sum calculations and considering the charge balance, the V is in the oxidation state +5, with no unpaired electrons) and the related ligands and vanadium oxide groups. As shown in Figures and 6S (), the χM T value of each Cu3 unit at 300 K is 1.27 cm3 K mol–1, being in agreement with the expected value of 1.24 cm3 K mol–1 for three magnetically isolated CuII ions (S = 1/2, g = 2.1). As the temperature decreases, the χM T product decreases down to a minimum value of 0.67 cm3 K mol–1 at 50 K, due to the antiferromagnetic coupling between the CuII atoms. Fitting the data at 75−300 K with the Curie–Weiss law gives C = 1.81 cm3 mol K–1 and θ = –112.3 K (Figure 7S, ). Below this temperature, the χM T product rises again and reaches a maximum value of 4.67 cm3 K mol–1 at 10 K, before eventually falling to 1.19 cm3 K mol–1 at 2.0 K, being probably ascribed to the saturation. The magnitude of the χM T maximum is field dependent, being larger at smaller applied fields. The shape of the susceptibility plot is also informative; as can be seen in Figure 8S, , the susceptibility rises sharply at 13 K, indicating spontaneous magnetization. The shape of the χM T versus T plot, with its minimum, is typical of ferrimagnetic behavior. Additionally, the zero-field cooled (ZFC) and field-cooled (FC) DC magnetic susceptibility curves deviate form each other at 10 K, indicating the onset of long-range order below this temperature (Figure , inset). The magnetization curve at 2.0 K, as shown in Figure , rises sharply to a saturation value of 1.1 Nβ, in agreement with an uncompensated S = 1/2 per asymmetric unit. The field dependence of the magnetization does not follow a Brillouin curve and shows a very small hysteresis at 2 K (Figure , inset), with a coercive field of less than 20 Oe, which agrees with a soft weak magnet. To further probe the long-range ordering in 1, the AC magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed with AC field frequencies between 0 and 1000 Hz (Figure 9S, ). A frequency independent signal appeared at T N = 10 K, indicating the onset of the long-range antiferromagnetic order. It should be pointed out that the χM ′ signal is not frequency-dependent, indicating that the order is three-dimensional, and the χM ″ peak is unsymmetrical and broadened, suggesting that more than one magnetic phase is present, as expected for the structure. Similar situations have also been found in two recently reported heterometallic ferrimagnetic systems.
elements.clean_text: The magnetic susceptibility data were collected in the temperature range of 2-300 K at an applied field of 10000 Oe. The field dependence was also checked, and the susceptibility data at temperatures below 50 K were measured at an additional applied field of 500 Oe. The molar susceptibilities are calculated using the Cu3 asymmetric unit of the crystal structure, which consists of three CuII atoms [one Cu(2) and two symmetry related Cu(1)] with S = 1/2 and four VV atoms (based on the bond valence sum calculations and considering the charge balance, the V is in the oxidation state +5, with no unpaired electrons) and the related ligands and vanadium oxide groups. As shown in Figures  and 6S (), the χM T value of each Cu3 unit at 300 K is 1.27 cm3 K mol-1, being in agreement with the expected value of 1.24 cm3 K mol-1 for three magnetically isolated CuII ions (S = 1/2, g = 2.1). As the temperature decreases, the χM T product decreases down to a minimum value of 0.67 cm3 K mol-1 at 50 K, due to the antiferromagnetic coupling between the CuII atoms. Fitting the data at 75-300 K with the Curie-Weiss law gives C = 1.81 cm3 mol K-1 and θ = -112.3 K (Figure 7S, ). Below this temperature, the χM T product rises again and reaches a maximum value of 4.67 cm3 K mol-1 at 10 K, before eventually falling to 1.19 cm3 K mol-1 at 2.0 K, being probably ascribed to the saturation. The magnitude of the χM T maximum is field dependent, being larger at smaller applied fields. The shape of the susceptibility plot is also informative; as can be seen in Figure 8S, , the susceptibility rises sharply at 13 K, indicating spontaneous magnetization. The shape of the χM T versus T plot, with its minimum, is typical of ferrimagnetic behavior. Additionally, the zero-field cooled (ZFC) and field-cooled (FC) DC magnetic susceptibility curves deviate form each other at 10 K, indicating the onset of long-range order below this temperature (Figure , inset). The magnetization curve at 2.0 K, as shown in Figure , rises sharply to a saturation value of 1.1 Nβ, in agreement with an uncompensated S = 1/2 per asymmetric unit. The field dependence of the magnetization does not follow a Brillouin curve and shows a very small hysteresis at 2 K (Figure , inset), with a coercive field of less than 20 Oe, which agrees with a soft weak magnet. To further probe the long-range ordering in 1, the AC magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed with AC field frequencies between 0 and 1000 Hz (Figure 9S, ). A frequency independent signal appeared at T N = 10 K, indicating the onset of the long-range antiferromagnetic order. It should be pointed out that the χM ' signal is not frequency-dependent, indicating that the order is three-dimensional, and the χM " peak is unsymmetrical and broadened, suggesting that more than one magnetic phase is present, as expected for the structure. Similar situations have also been found in two recently reported heterometallic ferrimagnetic systems.

elements.content: Considering the VV atom being diamagnetic, 1 is a very unusual example of a homospin ferrimagnet, also as a 3D heterometallic homospin ferrimagnet. The 3D structure of 1 can be considered as double vertex sharing triangular subunits linked by the pyrazine-tetrazole ligands into layers, and these layers are further linked into a 3D framework solid by the vanadium oxide groups, which possess no unpaired electrons but could mediate a weak exchange interaction between CuII atoms of neighboring layers. From the magnetic point of view, those triangular sublattices, as shown in Figures b and , (odd-sided polyhedron) may achieve the noncompensation in spin moments of CuII atoms, thereby showing ferrimagnetism. On the other hand, 1 can also be seen as two lattices, one formed by Cu(2) ions and the other by the Cu(1) ions, that contain CuII atoms in a 1:2 ratio. The antiferromagnetic coupling between the two lattices results in an uncompensated spin S = 1/2 per every three CuII atoms (Figures ). At temperatures below 10 K the uncompensated spins align parallel to each other, resulting in the ferrimagnetic long-range order observed.
elements.clean_text: Considering the VV atom being diamagnetic, 1 is a very unusual example of a homospin ferrimagnet, also as a 3D heterometallic homospin ferrimagnet. The 3D structure of 1 can be considered as double vertex sharing triangular subunits linked by the pyrazine-tetrazole ligands into layers, and these layers are further linked into a 3D framework solid by the vanadium oxide groups, which possess no unpaired electrons but could mediate a weak exchange interaction between CuII atoms of neighboring layers. From the magnetic point of view, those triangular sublattices, as shown in Figures b and , (odd-sided polyhedron) may achieve the noncompensation in spin moments of CuII atoms, thereby showing ferrimagnetism. On the other hand, 1 can also be seen as two lattices, one formed by Cu(2) ions and the other by the Cu(1) ions, that contain CuII atoms in a 1:2 ratio. The antiferromagnetic coupling between the two lattices results in an uncompensated spin S = 1/2 per every three CuII atoms (Figures ). At temperatures below 10 K the uncompensated spins align parallel to each other, resulting in the ferrimagnetic long-range order observed.

elements.content: Schematic representation of the spin alignment in 1 viewed along the b direction. The grey lines indicate the Cu−Cu pairs with sizable magnetic interaction.

elements.content: In summary, the assembly of diamagnetic vanadium oxide chains and 5-(pyrimidin-2-yl)tetrazolato-CuII complex layers gave a heterometallic homospin ferrimagnet with a 3D structure, as a new inorganic–organic complex material. This work presents a useful synthetic approach for the homospin ferrimagnet and demonstrates the importance of engineering inorganic–organic composites by selecting suitable inorganic oxometalates, secondary metal ions, and organic ligands in the field of molecular-based magnetic materials.
elements.clean_text: In summary, the assembly of diamagnetic vanadium oxide chains and 5-(pyrimidin-2-yl)tetrazolato-CuII complex layers gave a heterometallic homospin ferrimagnet with a 3D structure, as a new inorganic-organic complex material. This work presents a useful synthetic approach for the homospin ferrimagnet and demonstrates the importance of engineering inorganic-organic composites by selecting suitable inorganic oxometalates, secondary metal ions, and organic ligands in the field of molecular-based magnetic materials.

elements.content: The synthesis, elementary analysis, XRPD patterns, IR spectrum, TG-DTA plot, X-ray crystallographic data, and additional figures of the structures and magnetic properties (CIF, PDF). These materials available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text: The synthesis, elementary analysis, XRPD patterns, IR spectrum, TG-DTA plot, X-ray crystallographic data, and additional figures of the structures and magnetic properties (CIF, PDF). These materials available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
